title: 110_s1631
content: The "Small Business Emergency Fuel Assistance Act of 2007" establishes an emergency fuel assistance program for small businesses and farms dependent on fuel within the Department of Commerce. If the President determines a shortage of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates threatens the US citizens' well-being, a Federal energy emergency can be declared for up to 30 days. The President can declare a Federal energy emergency for up to 30 days if there is a shortage of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates threatening US citizens' well-being. The declaration must specify the period, circumstance, area, and products affected. The President can extend the declaration for up to 30 days, multiple times, or discontinue it before expiration. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF GRANTS. During an energy emergency declared by the President, the Secretary of Commerce can award grants to States for fuel supply interruptions based on a formula considering small businesses, fuel price increases, and other relevant factors. Each State must establish a State Allocation Plan. Each State must establish an allocation plan for distributing financial assistance to small businesses and farms, including application requirements demonstrating need and energy efficiency measures. The State must establish an allocation plan for distributing financial assistance to small businesses and farms, with preference given to those with a higher percentage of operating costs expended on fuel. Eligibility for grants under this Act is based on the average gross receipts or number of qualified employees of a small business or farm. The term "aggregate gross assets" is defined in the Internal Revenue Code. $100,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012 for the Department of Commerce to implement this Act.
